title-group.article-title: Lessons from the 2004 Asian tsunami: Epidemiological and nosological debates in the diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder in non-Western post-disaster communities

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychiatry, Christian Medical College, Vellore, India
2Centre for Psychiatric Research, Aarhus University hospital, Risskov, Denmark

author-notes.corresp: A. P. Rajkumar, Centre for Psychiatric Research, Aarhus University Hospital, 2, Skovagervej, 8240 Risskov, Denmark. Email: antoprajkumar@yahoo.com

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The nosological validity of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) remains controversial in non-Western communities. After natural disasters, epidemiological studies often overlook these conceptual debates and assess post-traumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) by short screening instruments. Such PTSS estimates are reported as inflated prevalence rates of PTSD in post-disaster settings.

sec.title: Aims:
sec.p: To discuss the prevalence and determinants of PTSS within the context of pertinent epidemiological and nosological debates.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We assessed PTSS and grief symptoms of 643 survivors from five Indian villages struck by the Asian tsunami using the Impact of Events Scale – Revised and Complicated Grief Assessment Scale. We adopted a case control design and employed complex sample multiple logistic regression statistics to study the determinants of PTSS.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The prevalence of PTSS was 15.1% (95% CI 12.3%–17.9%). PTSS was significantly associated with traumatic grief, female gender, physical injury, death of children and financial losses, but not with functional disability (p = .91).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Although PTSS were common in this population, elevating them to a psychiatric construct of PTSD is questionable, when functional impairment and avoidance behaviours were absent. Grief reactions, socio-economic burden, and poor support systems contribute towards PTSS. We highlight the important issues regarding the nosological validity and epidemiology of PTSD in non-Western communities.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) remains one of the most controversial medical constructs (Frueh et al., 2005; Hargrave, 2001; McHugh & Treisman, 2007; Summerfield, 2001; Wittchen, Gloster, Beesdo, Schönfeld, & Perkonigg, 2009). Arguments ranging from PTSD as a culture-specific disorder created by Western professionals (Summerfield, 2001) to PTSD as a genuine neuro-psychiatric disorder with specific neuro-endocrine deficits (Hull, 2002) exist simultaneously. Studies on PTSD increase in number following every large natural disaster (Noji, 2005). Prevalence rates of PTSD, reported by these studies, vary widely between 5% and 60% (Galea, Nandi, & Vlahov, 2005) due to changing definitions of PTSD over time, population characteristics, varying exposure levels, effect modifiers, the timing of the study and to the diagnostic overlap with traumatic grief (Prigerson, Shear, & Jacobs, 2000).

The Asian tsunami wreaked havoc along the south-eastern coast of India and resulted in devastating losses (Ashraf, 2005). Preliminary studies from India (Kumar et al., 2007) and Sri Lanka (Hollifield et al., 2008) were limited to one single affected village and have estimated prevalence of PTSD as 12.7% and 21%, respectively. Another Indian study on children and adolescents has claimed the prevalence rate of PTSD as high as 70.7% (John, Russell, & Russell, 2007).

Many post-disaster studies employ brief screening questionnaires to elicit post-traumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) and then elevate them into debatable PTSD diagnoses (Neria, Nandi, & Galea, 2008). They often overlook the nosological debates and epidemiological issues related to the diagnosis of PTSD in non-Western post-disaster settings. As larger epidemiological studies addressing these important issues are sparse, we report this study on the nature, prevalence and factors associated with PTSS in five severely affected coastal villages and present our findings within the context of pertinent epidemiological and nosological debates.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: We employed a cross-sectional study to examine the nature and prevalence of PTSS in affected coastal villages. We used a case control design framework to identify the factors associated with PTSS.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Nagapattinam district was the most affected, accounting for 6,065 of the 7,995 deaths, in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu (Government of Tamil Nadu, Disaster Management and Mitigation Department, 2005). The district is spread over 2,715.83 km2 and has a 147 km long coastline. It houses a population of 1,488,839 (Government of Tamil Nadu, 2001) and has a population per doctor ratio of 29,158:1 (Government of Tamil Nadu, Directorate of Medical & Rural Health Services, 2004). The study was conducted in five of the most devastated coastal villages, namely Thirumullaivaasal, Kizhamoovarkarai, Kottaimedu, Pudhukuppam and Poombuhar of the Nagapattinam district. These villages had a total population of 13,900 and suffered 352 deaths during the Asian tsunami.

sec.title: Sample size estimation
sec.p: Previous Indian studies following natural disasters have estimated the prevalence of PTSS at about 15%–20% (Sharan, Chaudhary, Kavathekar, & Saxena, 1996). As we anticipated the prevalence of PTSS in our population to be around 15%, we estimated, using the standard formula (4pq/d2), the prerequisite sample size as 567 with 5% alpha error, 80% a priori power and 3% precision.

sec.title: Sampling method
sec.p: We collected the data on these five coastal villages from the following sources: (1) District Collector’s office, Nagapattinam; (2) Christian Medical College (CMC), Vellore, health surveillance team for the tsunami-affected areas; and (3) Directorate of Census Operations – Tamil Nadu. As the overall sampling frame to carry out probabilistic sampling was not available due to extensive geographical relocation, migration and encumbered registration systems, we considered each village as a cluster and selected the households or temporary shelters by door-knocking method. Each investigator started with a specific row of households or temporary shelters and ensured avoiding any duplication of data. We recruited a maximum of two participants per household.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: All people living in the selected household were considered for possible inclusion if they satisfied the following criteria: (1) above 12 years of age; and (2) willing to provide their verbal informed consent to participate in the study. We excluded the respondents if they refused consent, or if they had severe physical or psychiatric illness or sensory impairment precluding the assessments performed.

sec.title: Assessment
sec.p: The following instruments were employed:

list-item.p: Impact of Events Scale – Revised (IES-R). The IES has been widely used to study the psychological impact of a variety of traumas (Horowitz, Wilner, & Alvarex, 1979). At least 66 studies investigating the reliability and validity of IES are available (Sundin & Horowitz, 2002). Along with the two-factor (avoidance and intrusion) structure of IES, IES-R also has a hyper-arousal subscale. It has 22 items, which are rated along a five-point Likert scale ranging from 0 to 4. Cut-off values of either the raw total scores or the means of subscales of IES-R were used to derive the diagnosis of PTSD in previous studies (Knaevelsrud & Maercker, 2007). We defined PTSS by the cut-off value of mean scores of 2 and above in all three subscales in this study (Wu & Chan, 2004).

Complicated Grief Assessment scale (CGA; Prigerson et al., 1999). This is a standard 12-item instrument that assesses the traumatic grief reactions within the previous one month. It identifies symptoms of separation distress and bereavement.
A structured questionnaire to assess the level of exposure to the tsunami waves.
A structured questionnaire to record the socio-demographic characteristics.

sec.title: Translation of instruments
sec.p: We employed Tamil versions of the IES-R and the CGA. The translation and back-translation process followed standard procedures with the use of bilingual translators, who reached a consensus agreement on the most appropriate translations with an emphasis on content and conceptual, semantic and technical equivalence.

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: A 10-member CMC tsunami psychosocial support team, including a professor of psychiatry, two qualified psychiatrists, two psychiatric nurses, one medical nurse, one occupational therapist and three social workers, collected the data. The non-psychiatric professionals of the team were provided training regarding the practical issues in psychiatric assessment, project methodology and use of assessment tools, during demonstrations, piloting the interview in the field and a workshop at the department of psychiatry, CMC, Vellore. We interviewed the participants in their own homes or temporary shelters during September 2005, nine months after the Asian tsunami. Each interview lasted about 60–90 minutes. A second interview was scheduled if the subject reported tiredness or difficulty in concentration during the interview. We visited a sample of randomly selected households for each investigator and re-interviewed participants. We re-checked all data collection sheets and a second check of 10% of randomly selected data collection sheets as well as data entry files for accuracy was done.

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: We provided detailed information regarding the purpose and the procedures of this study, emphasizing the voluntary nature of participation and the participants’ right to withdraw from the study at any time. We ensured that the participants provided their verbal informed consent voluntarily without any coercion. The protocol of this study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of CMC, Vellore. The CMC tsunami psychosocial support team provided appropriate interventions such as supportive counselling, grief counselling and periodic home visits for those with PTSS. We ensured referral and transport to the Department of Psychiatry, CMC, Vellore, when deemed necessary.

sec.title: Data analyses
sec.p: We initially analysed the socio-demographic data, psychosocial profile and data on PTSS using descriptive statistics. We analysed the observed differences between those with PTSS and those without, using appropriate tests for statistical significance. We imputed missing values by series mean and by median value of nearby points for continuous and categorical variables, respectively. We converted the continuous exposure variables to categorical measures by splitting them into two categories using their median values (Ragin, 1994). We calculated the odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals for various hypothesized risk factors. We adjusted for the effects of age, gender and education and for the clustering design effect of the villages by employing appropriate complex sample multiple logistic regression analyses. We analysed the data with statistical software packages SPSS 16.0 and STATA 10.0.

sec.title: Participant characteristics
sec.p: We recruited 643 consecutive participants satisfying the eligibility criteria. More than 90% of those invited to participate in the study consented. We present the socio-demographic and psychosocial profiles of the participants in Table 1. The majority of the participants were young adults, married, had primary school education and were living in temporary shelters at the time of the interview. Over half (54.4%) of the participants were mourning for the loss of their relatives. The vast majority (92%) had witnessed the tsunami and 88% had been physically caught up in the waves. There were no participants who had been diagnosed to have any psychiatric disorder before their exposure to the Asian tsunami of 2004.

sec.title: Nature and prevalence of PTSS
sec.p: Participants scored significantly less on the avoidance subscale when compared to hyper-arousal (Wilcoxon sign ranks Z = −3.90, p < .001) and the intrusion subscale of IES-R (Wilcoxon sign ranks Z = −11.80, p < .001). Caseness of PTSS was defined by having mean scores of 2 and above in all three subscales of IES-R. The prevalence of PTSS in our sample was 15.1% (95% CI 12.33%–17.87%). Those with PTSS and those without did not differ significantly on functional impairment, defined by their inability to return to their pre-disaster or equivalent occupation, following the tsunami (c2 = 0.013, df = 1, p = 0.91).

sec.title: Factors associated with PTSS
sec.p: We present the factors associated with PTSS in Table 2. Presence of traumatic grief, death of their children, physical injury, female gender, men handling corpses during tsunami relief work and reporting more financial losses were significantly associated with PTSS after adjustment for complex sample design effects and for age, gender and education. Adequate financial aid significantly protected against PTSS. We performed appropriate sensitivity analyses with only the participants without any missing data (n = 487) and by replacing the missing data with a neutral value. Such sensitivity analyses confirmed the significant associations between PTSS and the above-listed correlates. Participants with traumatic grief scored higher on the hyper-arousal (Mann-Whitney U = 12,421, p < .001), intrusion (Mann-Whitney U = 12,940, p < .001) and avoidance (Mann-Whitney U = 15,480, p < .001) subscales of IES-R, than those without grief symptoms.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study examined the nature, prevalence and factors associated with PTSS in a sample of people from five affected Indian coastal villages. Its strengths include an adequate sample size, timing of the study after the resolution of most of the acute stress reactions, assessing grief symptoms, a modest refusal rate and good quality control measures. Its limitations were its cross-sectional design and consequent temporal ambiguity.

The 15.1% prevalence estimate of PTSS was comparable to the prevalence rates of PTSD reported by earlier studies from the tsunami-affected villages in India and Sri Lanka (Hollifield et al., 2008; Kumar et al., 2007) and to the prevalence rates of PTSD reported from many post-disaster non-Western communities (Neria et al., 2008). The association with female gender and physical injury was also replicated (Kumar et al., 2007). Threat to life (Hollifield et al., 2008) and low income (Kumar et al., 2007) did not emerge as significant risk factors in this study. However, we differ from previous reports by not elevating these estimates of PTSS to the prevalence rates of PTSD. We realize that extrapolating these PTSS estimates into the psychiatric construct of PTSD diagnoses is debatable in our population, due to the following issues related to the nosological validity and epidemiology of PTSD.

sec.title: Nosological validity of PTSD in non-Western settings
sec.p: The concept of PTSD varies from a narrow categorical diagnosis to extensive dimensions of human distress following any ‘trauma’. The concordance rate of categorical clinical diagnosis of PTSD between the two major classificatory systems ICD-10 (World Health Organization, 1992) and DSM-IV (American Psychiatric Association, 1994) is less than satisfactory (Peters, Slade, & Andrews, 1999). DSM IV-TR requires a minimum of three avoidance symptoms, two hyper-arousal, one re-experiencing symptom, and clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational or other areas of functioning to make a reliable diagnosis of PTSD. None of our participants with PTSS satisfied these criteria for PTSD. Such criteria for PTSD may be inappropriate for our population, for the following reasons:

list-item.p: The expression ‘post’ in ‘post-traumatic stress disorder’ implies that the trauma is over and the subject continues to experience distressing symptoms despite his/her safety being ensured (Jacob, 2010). Hence, when the survivor is denied the luxury of moving to a safer territory and when the miseries of his/her post-disaster lifestyle are similar to the disaster per se, the validity of the concept of PTSD suffers.

The tsunami survivors had limited opportunities to avoid the stimuli associated with the trauma. They had to live in the temporary shelters near the seashore, to return to their destroyed dwellings to reconstruct their lives, and to the sea to ensure their livelihood. Cohesive social bonds and religious rituals facilitated talking about the event and collective mourning (Rajkumar, Titus, & Tharyan, 2008). Our focus group interviews have elicited their individual, social and spiritual coping strategies in detail (Rajkumar et al., 2008). Thus, avoidance symptoms sufficient to fulfil PTSD diagnostic criteria were distinctly absent in our population.

The threat of recurrence of the tsunami was genuinely real for the survivors residing in temporary shelters near the seashore, as evidenced by continuing media reports of tremors and potential tsunamis. The ensuing vigilance can also be argued as a protective mechanism that is explainable and not necessarily a pathological hyper-arousal phenomenon.

Intrusion or re-experiencing symptoms are common in grief reactions. Participants with grief symptoms had more PTSS than those without grief symptoms. Due to significant overlap between the conceptual and diagnostic boundaries between PTSD and traumatic grief (Prigerson et al., 2000), such symptoms failed to provide reliable diagnostic specificity in our population.

The assessment of clinically significant distress or functional impairment to qualify for a diagnosis of PTSD in displaced persons living in temporary settlements, used to traditional roles and deprived of their normal circumstances, was also questionable.

Debates on the public health utility of the medical construct of PTSD (Stein, Seedat, Iversen, & Wessely, 2007) and the limits of medicalizing human distress (Heath, 1999) remain unanswered in non-Western communities.

sec.title: Epidemiological issues in PTSD research
sec.p: The inconsistencies among the reported prevalence rates of PTSD and the reporting of exceptionally high rates of PTSD in a few isolated studies (John et al., 2007) provide the impetus to discuss the issues related to assessment methods and study designs in PTSD research in non-Western communities.

list-item.p: Validation studies of PTSD screening instruments tend to focus mostly on sensitivity indices and settle for specificity as low as 22% (John & Russell, 2007), which leads to more false positives and inflated prevalence rates of PTSD. Such a validated scale with 80% sensitivity and 22% specificity can overstate a true population prevalence of 5% into an imposing false prevalence estimate of 78.1%.

In an epidemiological study, true prevalence of any disorder is a function of test positivity rate as well as sensitivity and specificity of the employed screening instrument. PTSD surveys routinely project the test positivity rates as exaggerated estimates of true prevalence of PTSD. This strategy risks the survey estimates being representative of only false positives and not indicative of the true prevalence of PTSD. In a population without a single true case of PTSD, even an ideal scale with 90% sensitivity and 90% specificity can show up a survey estimate of 10% when the prevalence rate is not adjusted for the false positive cases.

The positive predictive value and false positivity rate of any assessment are dependent on the prevalence of the disease in that particular population (Jacob, 2003). Even if we assume the true prevalence of PTSD as 10% and the scale has a specificity of 80% and sensitivity of 80%, the calculated false positive rate will be 69.2% (Jacob, Senthilkumar, Gayathri, Abraham, & Prince, 2007). This supports the argument that at least 70% of identified cases are not true PTSD even if we assume an ideal scenario. When we combine a non-existent or a rare disease with screening instruments with low specificity, such an alliance can blow up false positivity rates and produce impressive, but flawed, prevalence estimates.

Affected villages differed in their level of exposure and the distribution of aid. Epidemiological studies neglecting the clustering effect of the villages and the need to employ complex sample statistical analyses, may report spurious factors associated with PTSD.

Any screening instrument has to be validated against a reference standard. However, a reference standard to diagnose PTSD has not been unequivocally identified so far, because the contemporary diagnostic criteria for PTSD are still evolving (Rosen, Spitzer, & McHugh, 2008; Rosenbaum, 2004; Spitzer, First, & Wakefield, 2007) and require further validation (North, Suris, Davis, & Smith, 2009). Moreover, clinical interviews have less positive predictive value in post-disaster settings than in hospital settings (Jacob, 2003). Hence, the validity of the available screening instruments for PTSD remains questionable.

There is no universal consensus over the reliable diagnostic cut-off values for the available PTSD screening instruments. The investigators are frequently lured to choose the cut-off values according to the prevalence rates of PTSD that they wish to produce (Hoge, Messer, & Castro, 2004).

Due to widespread geographical relocation, migration, missing persons and inefficient registration systems in resource-poor, non-Western post-disaster settings, the overall sampling frame to carry out probabilistic random sampling for epidemiological studies is almost impossible to obtain. The lack of a probabilistic sampling strategy compromises the generalizability of such study findings.

If an exposure variable is highly prevalent in a population, its association with the outcome variable cannot be reliably estimated using a case control design. This prevents the study of the association between PTSD and important factors in post-disaster settings such as pending aid and direct exposure to the waves in non-Western communities.

sec.title: PTSS or PTSD?
sec.p: As answers for these complex debates are not readily available at present, we suggest caution in interpreting the results of available PTSD prevalence studies in post-disaster settings, especially from non-Western communities. We acknowledge the fact that our findings represent only PTSS and not the psychiatric construct PTSD. Diagnosing a clinically valid syndrome (PTSD) is different from counting the symptoms (PTSS), disregarding their contextual significance. Neglecting these nosological and epidemiological debates may not help to advance the understanding of PTSD at both the individual and the population level. We suggest future epidemiological studies on PTSD to consider these issues seriously, to avoid over-diagnosing and over-reporting PTSD in post-disaster communities. Longitudinal cross-cultural studies to clarify these nosological debates are desired.
